content.text: - Title: Time Series Analysis and Forecasting
- Course number: TOKT11122E
- Type of course: Compulsory
- Credits: 3
+ Lecture 30 hours
+ Tutorial 15 hours
+ Self-study 90 hours
- Prerequisite: EP15.TOKT1105, EP15.TOKT11108
Department: Mathematical Economics
Address: Suite 1105, Building A1, NEU
Instructor:
TBD,

This course provides an introduction to time series analysis, highlighting its applications in the stock market and includes setting up Anaconda Python and Jupyter. Starting with NumPy, students will learn about arrays, indexing, and operations, applying these to create stock market indicators such as SMA, EMA, MACD, and RSI through hands-on exercises. The focus then shifts to Pandas for data handling and analysis, teaching students about Series, DataFrames, and data visualization, with practical exercises on stock market data. Students will explore visualizing financial time series and delve into advanced analysis with Statsmodels, covering error, trend, and seasonality decomposition. The curriculum includes forecasting models, from basics to complex concepts like ARIMA, SARIMA, and GARCH models, complemented by code-along sessions. By the course's end, students understand how to apply time series in analyzing and forecasting stock market trends with Python's powerful libraries, ready to apply these skills in financial contexts.
[1] Gebhard Kirchgässner, Jürgen Wolters (2013), Introduction to Modern Time Series Analysis, Springer.
[2] Wes McKinney (2022), Python for Data Analysis, O’Reilly Media.
[3] Eryk Lewinson (2022), Python for Finance Cookbook, Packt Publishing.
[4] Tarek A. Atwan (2022), Time Series Analysis with Python Cookbook: Practical recipes for exploratory data analysis, data preparation, forecasting, and model evaluation, Packt Publishing.
[5] Changquan Huang and Alla Petukhina (2022), Applied Time Series Analysis and Forecasting with Python, Springer.
[6] Ben Auffarth (2021), Machine Learning for Time-Series with Python, Packt Publishing.
[7] Francesca Lazzeri (2020), Machine Learning for Time Series Forecasting with Python, Wiley.
[8] https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat510/

cells: Understand the background of time series analysis, highlighting its core concepts and applications in stock market, finance, economics, and related fields.

column_map.Description: Understand the background of time series analysis, highlighting its core concepts and applications in stock market, finance, economics, and related fields.

Achieve a participant score of 5.0 or higher.
Must join projects
Actively contribute to the lesson.
Engage with the textbook and complete projects.
Avoid eating or using cell phones during class.
Use of laptops and iPads is permitted only for practice and calculation purposes.

full_text:
- Title: Time Series Analysis and Forecasting
- Course number: TOKT11122E
- Type of course: Compulsory
- Credits: 3
+ Lecture 30 hours
+ Tutorial 15 hours
+ Self-study 90 hours
- Prerequisite: EP15.TOKT1105, EP15.TOKT11108
Department: Mathematical Economics
Address: Suite 1105, Building A1, NEU
Instructor:
TBD,
This course provides an introduction to time series analysis, highlighting its applications in the stock market and includes setting up Anaconda Python and Jupyter. Starting with NumPy, students will learn about arrays, indexing, and operations, applying these to create stock market indicators such as SMA, EMA, MACD, and RSI through hands-on exercises. The focus then shifts to Pandas for data handling and analysis, teaching students about Series, DataFrames, and data visualization, with practical exercises on stock market data. Students will explore visualizing financial time series and delve into advanced analysis with Statsmodels, covering error, trend, and seasonality decomposition. The curriculum includes forecasting models, from basics to complex concepts like ARIMA, SARIMA, and GARCH models, complemented by code-along sessions. By the course's end, students understand how to apply time series in analyzing and forecasting stock market trends with Python's powerful libraries, ready to apply these skills in financial contexts.
[1] Gebhard Kirchgässner, Jürgen Wolters (2013), Introduction to Modern Time Series Analysis, Springer.
[2] Wes McKinney (2022), Python for Data Analysis, O’Reilly Media.
[3] Eryk Lewinson (2022), Python for Finance Cookbook, Packt Publishing.
[4] Tarek A. Atwan (2022), Time Series Analysis with Python Cookbook: Practical recipes for exploratory data analysis, data preparation, forecasting, and model evaluation, Packt Publishing.
[5] Changquan Huang and Alla Petukhina (2022), Applied Time Series Analysis and Forecasting with Python, Springer.
[6] Ben Auffarth (2021), Machine Learning for Time-Series with Python, Packt Publishing.
[7] Francesca Lazzeri (2020), Machine Learning for Time Series Forecasting with Python, Wiley.
[8] https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat510/
Ensure at least 80% attendance in the class.
Achieve a participant score of 5.0 or higher.
Must join projects
Actively contribute to the lesson.
Engage with the textbook and complete projects.
Avoid eating or using cell phones during class.
Use of laptops and iPads is permitted only for practice and calculation purposes.
